description: Test your knowledge of sports history, rules, and legendary athletes

questions.question: Which country won the first FIFA World Cup in 1930?
questions.funFact: This country won the tournament on home soil, defeating Argentina 4-2 in the final!
questions.story: The first World Cup was played entirely in Montevideo, Uruguay. Only 13 teams participated, with many European nations declining due to the long travel time by boat. Uruguay was chosen as host partly because they were celebrating their 100th anniversary of independence.

questions.question: In which sport would you perform a 'slam dunk'?
questions.funFact: The slam dunk was banned in college from 1967 to 1976, largely due to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's dominance!
questions.story: The term 'slam dunk' was coined by Los Angeles Lakers announcer Chick Hearn in 1972. Before that, it was simply called a 'dunk shot'. The move has become one of basketball's most exciting plays and a symbol of athletic excellence.

questions.question: How many Olympic rings are there?
questions.funFact: The rings represent the union of the five continents and the meeting of athletes from around the world!
questions.story: The Olympic rings were designed by Baron Pierre de Coubertin in 1912. The colors (blue, yellow, black, green, and red) were chosen because at least one of these colors appeared on every country's flag at the time.

questions.question: Which Olympic sport never gets wet?
questions.funFact: Players can swim up to 5 kilometers during a single game!
questions.story: Water polo originated in Great Britain in the late 19th century as a form of rugby played in rivers and lakes. The modern game evolved significantly, with players treading water the entire time, never touching the pool bottom. The sport requires incredible endurance and strength.

questions.question: Which sport was played on the moon?
questions.funFact: The ball traveled much farther than it would on Earth!
questions.story: During the Apollo 14 mission in 1971, astronaut Alan Shepard became the first person to play golf on the moon. He used a makeshift club head attached to a sample collection tool and hit two golf balls, demonstrating the moon's lower gravity.

questions.question: Which sport has square courts?
questions.funFact: This sport holds the world record for ball speed!
questions.story: Jai Alai, originating from the Basque region, is played in a three-walled court called a fronton. The curved wicker basket (cesta) used to catch and throw the ball makes this sport unique. The pelota (ball) can reach speeds over 150 miles per hour.

questions.question: Which sport never has ties?
questions.funFact: This sport was once banned in the Soviet Union!
questions.story: Table tennis matches always produce a winner due to its scoring system. The sport was banned in the USSR from 1930 to 1950 because authorities believed it was harmful to players' eyes. Today, it's one of the most popular indoor sports worldwide.

questions.question: Which sport originated in prison?
questions.funFact: The original game used fruit baskets instead of nets!
questions.story: Dr. James Naismith invented basketball in 1891 at a YMCA training school to keep athletes indoors during winter. The first game used peach baskets nailed to the gym balcony, and someone had to retrieve the ball after each score.

questions.question: Which sport has the oldest trophy?
questions.funFact: The trophy was once used to serve ice cream!
questions.story: The America's Cup, first awarded in 1851, is the oldest trophy in international sports. Queen Victoria watched the first race around the Isle of Wight. The trophy, made of solid silver, was once used to serve ice cream at a party in New York.

questions.question: Which sport uses a kitchen?
questions.funFact: This sport was invented to entertain bored children!
questions.story: Pickleball, created in 1965 on Bainbridge Island, Washington, features a 'kitchen' - a non-volley zone near the net. The game combines elements of tennis, badminton, and table tennis, and was named after the inventor's family dog, Pickles.

questions.question: Which sport has no time limit?
questions.funFact: The longest match of this sport lasted 12 days!
questions.story: Test cricket matches can last up to five days without a guaranteed result. The longest recorded cricket match was between England and South Africa in 1939, which was abandoned after 12 days because the English team had to catch their ship home.

questions.question: Which sport invented cheerleading?
questions.funFact: The first cheerleaders were all male!
questions.story: Cheerleading began at the University of Minnesota in 1898 when student Johnny Campbell led the crowd in cheering at a football game. Initially, it was an all-male activity, and women weren't allowed to participate until World War II.

questions.question: Which sport never uses new balls?
questions.funFact: This sport is played by British royalty!
questions.story: Real Tennis, the original form of tennis, uses hand-made balls that improve with age. The balls are made of cork wrapped in fabric and hand-stitched with felt. They become faster and more predictable as they age, unlike modern tennis balls.

questions.question: Which sport was played in pajamas?
questions.funFact: The original dress code was very strict!
questions.story: In the 1800s, tennis was played in formal sleepwear because it was considered a leisurely activity. Players wore long-sleeved pajama-like garments that were deemed appropriate for the Victorian era's standards of modesty.

questions.question: Which Olympic sport had a pillow fight?
questions.funFact: The event lasted for three Olympic Games!
questions.story: Solo synchronized swimming was an Olympic sport from 1984 to 1992. During one memorable performance, an athlete incorporated a pillow fight sequence into her routine, pushing the boundaries of artistic interpretation.

questions.question: Which sport uses a concrete ball?
questions.funFact: These balls can weigh up to 2 pounds!
questions.story: Traditional Italian bocce balls were made from compressed concrete covered with epoxy. This unique construction method started in the 1800s when metal was scarce, and the tradition continued even after metal became readily available.

questions.question: Which sport requires singing?
questions.funFact: Players must hold their breath during play!
questions.story: In Kabaddi, raiders must continuously chant 'kabaddi' while in enemy territory to prove they're not breathing. This ancient sport originated in India and combines elements of wrestling and tag.

questions.question: Which sport has square balls?
questions.funFact: The game was developed in ancient Greece!
questions.story: Boccia, a Paralympic sport, originally used square leather balls in its early development. The unique shape was designed to make the game more challenging and unpredictable for players.

questions.question: Which sport started in prison?
questions.funFact: The original name was 'Mintonette'!
questions.story: Volleyball was invented by William G. Morgan at the Holyoke YMCA, which was housed in a former prison building. He created the game as a less intense alternative to basketball for older members.

questions.question: Which sport uses mirrors?
questions.funFact: Athletes train blindfolded!
questions.story: Artistic swimmers use underwater mirrors during practice to perfect their movements. The mirrors, installed at the bottom of pools, help teams synchronize their routines and maintain precise formations.

questions.question: Which sport has moving targets?
questions.funFact: The sport was invented by chicken farmers!
questions.story: Skeet shooting was developed in Massachusetts in 1920 by chicken farmers who wanted to improve their aim for hunting. The moving targets simulate the unpredictable flight patterns of birds.

questions.question: Which sport uses invisible balls?
questions.funFact: The court is marked with string!
questions.story: Goalball, a Paralympic sport, uses a ball with bells inside but no visible markings. Players rely entirely on sound to track and catch the ball, making it a unique test of spatial awareness.

questions.question: Which sport requires silence?
questions.funFact: The sport has unusual scoring terms!
questions.story: Real Tennis, the original form of tennis played by royalty, requires complete silence during play. The tradition dates back to when matches were played in monastery courtyards, where noise was forbidden.

questions.question: Which sport climbs highest?
questions.funFact: The achievement was remarkable!
questions.story: The highest recorded sports activity was mountaineering on Mount Everest, where climbers reached 29,029 feet (8,848 meters) without supplemental oxygen.

questions.question: Which sport dives deepest?
questions.funFact: The dive lasted minutes!
questions.story: Herbert Nitsch, known as 'The Deepest Man on Earth', set the world record for freediving by reaching a depth of 253.2 meters (831 feet) in 2012.

questions.question: Which sport runs longest?
questions.funFact: The race spans seasons!
questions.story: The Self-Transcendence 3100 Mile Race is the world's longest certified footrace, where runners must complete 3,100 miles in 52 days around a single block in Queens, New York.

questions.question: Which sport spins fastest?
questions.funFact: The rotation is incredible!
questions.story: Russian figure skater Lucinda Ruh holds the Guinness World Record for the fastest spin on ice, completing 115 rotations in a single spin.

questions.question: Which sport throws farthest?
questions.funFact: The distance is amazing!
questions.story: Jan Železný holds the world record for javelin throw at 98.48 meters (323 feet), set in 1996, which is longer than a football field.

questions.question: Which sport has oldest player?
questions.funFact: He played professionally at 55!
questions.story: Kazuyoshi Miura, nicknamed 'King Kazu', became the world's oldest professional soccer player at 55 years old, playing for Yokohama FC in Japan's J-League in 2022.

questions.question: Which sport changes balls most?
questions.funFact: Balls are replaced every 7-9 games!
questions.story: Professional tennis matches use new balls every seven to nine games. At Wimbledon alone, about 54,000 balls are used during the tournament, replaced frequently to maintain consistent play.

questions.question: Which sport has highest jump?
questions.funFact: The jump was higher than the Statue of Liberty!
questions.story: Robbie Maddison set the world record for the highest motorcycle jump in 2009, reaching 351 feet (107 meters) in height during the Red Bull X-Fighters event in Madrid.

questions.question: Which sport plays underwater?
questions.funFact: Players wear snorkels!
questions.story: Octopush, also known as underwater hockey, was invented in 1954 by Alan Blake in England. Players use short sticks to push a puck across the pool bottom while holding their breath.

questions.question: Which sport has longest match?
questions.funFact: The match lasted three days!
questions.story: The longest tennis match in history was played at Wimbledon in 2010 between John Isner and Nicolas Mahut, lasting 11 hours and 5 minutes over three days, with Isner winning 70-68 in the final set.
